SafetyInspectionBy: IA Dept. of Ag & Land Stewardship

_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: This facility complies with applicable building, electrical, and plumbing codes which are deemed applicable by the jurisdictional authority.
_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: State of Iowa, Chapter 43, Fertilizer and Agricultural Lime, 21-43.6 (200)
_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: Administrative controls (operation procedures in place, speed limt, etc.), load-out riser breakaway system and a remote manual emergency shut-off valve at the storage tanks.
_prev_prog_2.MD_OtherType: Routine Visual Inspections by trained operators
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Storage tanks, and associated piping and transfer equipment
_prev_prog_2.Description:
The primary activity at this facility is storage and buying of grain from local farmers. The facility also has storage of fertilizers for sale to the farmers in the area. Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored and distributed for direct application as a nutrient for crop production.



The plan is to minimize those hazards to human health and to the environment that are associated with accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  Employees, working at the bulk storage plant, make routine observations and inspections prior to and during transfer operations of anhydrous ammonia from the storage vessel(s) into nurse tanks.  In so doing, they are able to detect problems before they arise. Repairs can be made before they become problematic.  Employees are annually trained to recognize the hazards associated with storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia.  In addition to annual training several employees who have been on the job for a number of years. This training includes classroom instruction, oral testing, on-site training at the plant, and follow-up observation to determine their individual comprehension and understanding of working with anhydrous ammonia.  



The company routinely invites local fire department personnel to visit the site.

_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: State of Iowa, Chapter 43, Fertilizer and Agricultural Lime, 21-43.6 (200)

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary



Facility:  Cogdill Farm Supply, Inc.

    104 West Fulton    

    Dow City, IA  51528

Contact:  Robert P. Cogdill

Phone:   712-674-3344



1.    Facility Policy.



        The owners, management and employees of Cogdill Farm Supply, Inc. are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, Crawford Emergency Management/County LEPC, and/or other authorities, to mitigate and minimize the impacts of the release to the people and the environment.



2.    Facility Information.



        The primary activity at the facility is the distribution of products to area farmers.  The fertilizer product, anhydrous ammonia is received, stored and distributed for direct application as a nutrient for crop production.  At times, Anhydrous ammonia is also stored on site in nurse tanks designed for this purpose.  The facility is manned year round during normal business hours.



3.    The Worst-Case Release Scenario and the Alternate Release Scenario 



         An analysis of the potential off-site consequences of hypothetical worst-case and alternative-case accidental releases have been addressed in our Hazard Assessment and information is in our Risk Management Program.



4.    Accidental Release Prevention Program



        The facility is in compliance with the provisions of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia" and state regulations covering anhydrous ammonia.  The OSHA standard is referenced in this RMP Registration Form; see Section 8.3 (b).



5.    Five-Year Accident History.



        There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that have caused any deaths, injuries or significant property damage at the facility; nor to our knowledge, has THERE BEEN ANY ACCIDENTAL RELEASES resulting in o

ff-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, property damage, or environmental damage.



6.    Emergency Action Plan.



         The facility has:



          a.   A written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard

                29 CFR 1910.38;



          b.   Provided state and local authorities with the emergency planning and

                Community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III

                (EPCRA);



          c.   If a large release of anhydrous ammonia takes place at the facility,

                the required response action is to evacuate the area of the release and

                call 911 and all applicable emergency response numbers listed in our

                Emergency Action Plan.



7.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety.



        Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the conditions at our facility.   There are no additional specific safety recommendations regarding storage or use of anhydrous ammonia for implementation at this time.
